ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is a thorough and extremely well presented dive into intermediate/advanced French grammar and beginner/intermediate French literature and cultural texts.
My French definitely improved this semester. However, would advise against taking it if you don't want a high workload in the semester and are expecting something easier.
I gained a deeper confidence in my abilities with the language, in addition to learning a lot more about pieces of literature I had heard of but had never been able to read before.
I gained a noticeable amount of ease communicating and writing in French!
French speaking, writing, and reading skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course moves quickly -- it is essential to stay on top of work and ask questions as they arise. There is little opportunity to go back over material in detail that may not have been abundantly clear the first time around.

I loved this course. However, I wish we had been able to practice conversation more. It felt like much of the in-class discussion consisted of the instructor speaking a lot and students giving one or two-word answers. Also, the quality of the audio exercises was often poor and/or didn't match the worksheets.

Strengths is that if you want to improve in the language, it definitely allows you to do that. Weaknesses would be that I wish there was a little less emphasis on grammar rules and structure and more on improving the workability of the course.

I think this course really is brilliant. Sure, you have to do mountains of work, but the end result of confidence and flexibility with French is a huge benefit. The only weakness I would say is the fact that some texts are a bit rushed. I think we could have done without a couple of the diversity stories and instead spent much longer digesting and learning about sac de billes. Overall a great class; it's a shame that future L4 students won't get to learn from Mme Koizim, who has been a splendid professor over the last two semesters.

It might be an unpopular opinion, but I really enjoyed the intense reading of this course. On the other hand, recorded oral production questions felt extremely frustrating and an unnatural way to communicate. The syllabi were also all over the place, and it was difficult to know what was due.
At times the workload with the reading (especially having assigned readings after tests) is a bit much

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Despite the significant workload, French 140 is an extremely useful class to take and leaves you feeling much more confident in French grammar and language skills.
I absolutely would. If you want to become more handy with your French skills while absorbing more about literature, this is the class for you.
Absolutely the teachers are amazing and the material is taught very well
Yes to another wanting to take french.
